column2: CHAPTER XXVII.
column3: CHAPTER twenty seven.

column2: It was a hard blow to poor Sellers to see the work on his darling enterprise stop, and the noise and bustle and confusion that had been such refreshment to his soul, sicken and die out.
column3: It was a hard blow to poor Sellers to see the work on his darling enterprise stop, and the noise and bustle and confusion that had been such refreshment to his soul, sicken and die out.

column2: It was hard to come down to humdrum ordinary life again after being a General Superintendent and the most conspicuous man in the community.
column3: It was hard to come down to humdrum ordinary life again after being a General Superintendent and the most conspicuous man in the community.

column2: It was sad to see his name disappear from the newspapers; sadder still to see it resurrected at intervals, shorn of its aforetime gaudy gear of compliments and clothed on with rhetorical tar and feathers.
column3: It was sad to see his name disappear from the newspapers; sadder still to see it resurrected at intervals, shorn of its aforetime gaudy gear of compliments and clothed on with rhetorical tar and feathers.

column2: But his friends suffered more on his account than he did.
column3: But his friends suffered more on his account than he did.

column2: He was a cork that could not be kept under the water many moments at a time.
column3: He was a cork that could not be kept under the water many moments at a time.

column2: He had to bolster up his wife's spirits every now and then.
column3: He had to bolster up his wife's spirits every now and then.

column2: On one of these occasions he said:
column3: On one of these occasions he said:

column2: It's all right, my dear, all right; it will all come right in a little while.	It's all right, my dear, all right; it will all come right in a little while.
column3: true

column2: There's $200,000 coming, and that will set things booming again: Harry seems to be having some difficulty, but that's to be expected--you can't move these big operations to the tune of Fisher's Hornpipe, you know.
column3: There's two hundred thousand dollars coming, and that will set things booming again: Harry seems to be having some difficulty, but that's to be expected-you can't move these big operations to the tune of Fisher's Hornpipe, you know.

column2: But Harry will get it started along presently, and then you'll see!
column3: But Harry will get it started along presently, and then you'll see!

column2: I expect the news every day now."
column3: I expect the news every day now."

column2: But Beriah, you've been expecting it every day, all along, haven't you?
column3: But Beriah, you've been expecting it every day, all along, haven't you?

column2: Well, yes; yes--I don't know but I have.	Well, yes; yes-I don't know but I have.
column3: true

column2: But anyway, the longer it's delayed, the nearer it grows to the time when it will start--same as every day you live brings you nearer to--nearer--"
column3: But anyway, the longer it's delayed, the nearer it grows to the time when it will start-same as every day you live brings you nearer to-nearer-"

column2: The grave?
column3: The grave?

column2: Well, no--not that exactly; but you can't understand these things, Polly dear--women haven't much head for business, you know.	Well, no-not that exactly; but you can't understand these things, Polly dear-women haven't much head for business, you know.
column3: true

column2: You make yourself perfectly comfortable, old lady, and you'll see how we'll trot this right along.
column3: You make yourself perfectly comfortable, old lady, and you'll see how we'll trot this right along.

column2: Why bless you, let the appropriation lag, if it wants to--that's no great matter--there's a bigger thing than that."
column3: Why bless you, let the appropriation lag, if it wants to-that's no great matter-there's a bigger thing than that."

column2: Bigger than $200,000, Beriah?
column3: Bigger than two hundred thousand dollars, Beriah?

column2: Bigger, child?--why, what's $200,000?	Bigger, child?--why, what's two hundred thousand dollars?
column3: true

column2: Pocket money!
column3: Pocket money!

column2: Mere pocket money! Look at the railroad!
column3: Mere pocket money! Look at the railroad!

column2: Did you forget the railroad?
column3: Did you forget the railroad?

column2: It ain't many months till spring; it will be coming right along, and the railroad swimming right along behind it.
column3: It ain't many months till spring; it will be coming right along, and the railroad swimming right along behind it.

column2: Where'll it be by the middle of summer?
column3: Where'll it be by the middle of summer?

column2: Just stop and fancy a moment--just think a little--don't anything suggest itself? Bless your heart, you dear women live right in the present all the time--but a man, why a man lives----
column3: Just stop and fancy a moment-just think a little-don't anything suggest itself? Bless your heart, you dear women live right in the present all the time-but a man, why a man lives----

column2: In the future, Beriah?	In the future, Beriah?
column3: true

column2: But don't we live in the future most too much, Beriah?
column3: But don't we live in the future most too much, Beriah?

column2: We do somehow seem to manage to live on next year's crop of corn and potatoes as a general thing while this year is still dragging along, but sometimes it's not a robust diet,--Beriah.
column3: We do somehow seem to manage to live on next year's crop of corn and potatoes as a general thing while this year is still dragging along, but sometimes it's not a robust diet,--Beriah.

column2: But don't look that way, dear--don't mind what I say.
column3: But don't look that way, dear-don't mind what I say.

column2: I don't mean to fret, I don't mean to worry; and I don't, once a month, do I, dear?
column3: I don't mean to fret, I don't mean to worry; and I don't, once a month, do I, dear?

column2: But when I get a little low and feel bad, I get a bit troubled and worrisome, but it don't mean anything in the world.
column3: But when I get a little low and feel bad, I get a bit troubled and worrisome, but it don't mean anything in the world.

column2: It passes right away.
column3: It passes right away.

column2: I know you're doing all you can, and I don't want to seem repining and ungrateful--for I'm not, Beriah--you know I'm not, don't you?"
column3: I know you're doing all you can, and I don't want to seem repining and ungrateful-for I'm not, Beriah-you know I'm not, don't you?"

column2: Lord bless you, child, I know you are the very best little woman that ever lived--that ever lived on the whole face of the Earth!	Lord bless you, child, I know you are the very best little woman that ever lived-that ever lived on the whole face of the Earth!
column3: false

column2: And I know that I would be a dog not to work for you and think for you and scheme for you with all my might.
column3: And I know that I would be a dog not to work for you and think for you and scheme for you with all my might.

column2: And I'll bring things all right yet, honey--cheer up and don't you fear.
column3: And I'll bring things all right yet, honey-cheer up and don't you fear.

column2: The railroad----"
column3: The railroad----"

column2: Oh, I had forgotten the railroad, dear, but when a body gets blue, a body forgets everything.	Oh, I had forgotten the railroad, dear, but when a body gets blue, a body forgets everything.
column3: true

column2: Yes, the railroad--tell me about the railroad."
column3: Yes, the railroad-tell me about the railroad."

column2: Aha, my girl, don't you see?	Aha, my girl, don't you see?
column3: false

column2: Things ain't so dark, are they?
column3: Things ain't so dark, are they?

column2: Now I didn't forget the railroad.
column3: Now I didn't forget the railroad.

column2: Now just think for a moment--just figure up a little on the future dead moral certainties.
column3: Now just think for a moment-just figure up a little on the future dead moral certainties.

column2: For instance, call this waiter St. Louis.
column3: For instance, call this waiter saint Louis.

column2: And we'll lay this fork (representing the railroad) from St. Louis to this potato, which is Slouchburg:	And we'll lay this fork (representing the railroad) from saint Louis to this potato, which is Slouchburg:
column3: true

column2: Then with this carving knife we'll continue the railroad from Slouchburg to Doodleville, shown by the black pepper:	Then with this carving knife we'll continue the railroad from Slouchburg to Doodleville, shown by the black pepper:
column3: true

column2: Then we run along the--yes--the comb--to the tumbler that's Brimstone:	Then we run along the-yes-the comb-to the tumbler that's Brimstone:
column3: true

column2: Thence by the pipe to Belshazzar, which is the salt-cellar:	Thence by the pipe to Belshazzar, which is the salt cellar:
column3: true

column2: Thence to, to--that quill--Catfish--hand me the pincushion, Marie Antoinette:	Thence to, to-that quill-Catfish-hand me the pincushion, Marie Antoinette:
column3: true

column2: Thence right along these shears to this horse, Babylon:	Thence right along these shears to this horse, Babylon:
column3: true

column2: Then by the spoon to Bloody Run--thank you, the ink:	Then by the spoon to Bloody Run-thank you, the ink:
column3: true

column2: Thence to Hail Columbia--snuffers, Polly, please move that cup and saucer close up, that's Hail Columbia:	Thence to Hail Columbia-snuffers, Polly, please move that cup and saucer close up, that's Hail Columbia:
column3: true

column2: Then--let me open my knife--to Hark-from-the-Tomb, where we'll put the candle-stick--only a little distance from Hail Columbia to Hark-from-the-Tomb--down-grade all the way.	Then-let me open my knife-to Hark from the Tomb, where we'll put the candle stick-only a little distance from Hail Columbia to Hark from the Tomb-down grade all the way.
column3: false

column2: And there we strike Columbus River--pass me two or three skeins of thread to stand for the river; the sugar bowl will do for Hawkeye, and the rat trap for Stone's Landing--Napoleon, I mean--and you can see how much better Napoleon is located than Hawkeye.	And there we strike Columbus River-pass me two or three skeins of thread to stand for the river; the sugar bowl will do for Hawkeye, and the rat trap for Stone's Landing-Napoleon, I mean-and you can see how much better Napoleon is located than Hawkeye.
column3: true

column2: Now here you are with your railroad complete, and showing its continuation to Hallelujah and thence to Corruptionville.
column3: Now here you are with your railroad complete, and showing its continuation to Hallelujah and thence to Corruptionville.

column2: Now then--there you are!	Now then-there you are!
column3: true

column2: It's a beautiful road, beautiful.
column3: It's a beautiful road, beautiful.

column2: Jeff Thompson can out-engineer any civil engineer that ever sighted through an aneroid, or a theodolite, or whatever they call it--he calls it sometimes one and sometimes the other just whichever levels off his sentence neatest, I reckon.
column3: Jeff Thompson can out engineer any civil engineer that ever sighted through an aneroid, or a theodolite, or whatever they call it-he calls it sometimes one and sometimes the other just whichever levels off his sentence neatest, I reckon.

column2: But ain't it a ripping road, though?
column3: But ain't it a ripping road, though?

column2: I tell you, it'll make a stir when it gets along.
column3: I tell you, it'll make a stir when it gets along.

column2: Just see what a country it goes through.
column3: Just see what a country it goes through.

column2: There's your onions at Slouchburg--noblest onion country that graces God's footstool; and there's your turnip country all around Doodleville--bless my life, what fortunes are going to be made there when they get that contrivance perfected for extracting olive oil out of turnips--if there's any in them; and I reckon there is, because Congress has made an appropriation of money to test the thing, and they wouldn't have done that just on conjecture, of course.
column3: There's your onions at Slouchburg-noblest onion country that graces God's footstool; and there's your turnip country all around Doodleville-bless my life, what fortunes are going to be made there when they get that contrivance perfected for extracting olive oil out of turnips-if there's any in them; and I reckon there is, because Congress has made an appropriation of money to test the thing, and they wouldn't have done that just on conjecture, of course.

column2: And now we come to the Brimstone region--cattle raised there till you can't rest--and corn, and all that sort of thing.
column3: And now we come to the Brimstone region-cattle raised there till you can't rest-and corn, and all that sort of thing.

column2: Then you've got a little stretch along through Belshazzar that don't produce anything now--at least nothing but rocks--but irrigation will fetch it.
column3: Then you've got a little stretch along through Belshazzar that don't produce anything now-at least nothing but rocks-but irrigation will fetch it.

column2: Then from Catfish to Babylon it's a little swampy, but there's dead loads of peat down under there somewhere.
column3: Then from Catfish to Babylon it's a little swampy, but there's dead loads of peat down under there somewhere.

column2: Next is the Bloody Run and Hail Columbia country--tobacco enough can be raised there to support two such railroads.
column3: Next is the Bloody Run and Hail Columbia country-tobacco enough can be raised there to support two such railroads.

column2: Next is the sassparilla region.
column3: Next is the sassparilla region.

column2: I reckon there's enough of that truck along in there on the line of the pocket-knife, from Hail Columbia to Hark-from-the Tomb to fat up all the consumptives in all the hospitals from Halifax to the Holy Land.
column3: I reckon there's enough of that truck along in there on the line of the pocket knife, from Hail Columbia to Hark from the Tomb to fat up all the consumptives in all the hospitals from Halifax to the Holy Land.

column2: It just grows like weeds!
column3: It just grows like weeds!

column2: I've got a little belt of sassparilla land in there just tucked away unobstrusively waiting for my little Universal Expectorant to get into shape in my head.
column3: I've got a little belt of sassparilla land in there just tucked away unobstrusively waiting for my little Universal Expectorant to get into shape in my head.

column2: And I'll fix that, you know.
column3: And I'll fix that, you know.

column2: One of these days I'll have all the nations of the earth expecto--"
column3: One of these days I'll have all the nations of the earth expecto-"

column2: But Beriah, dear--
column3: But Beriah, dear-

column2: Don't interrupt me; Polly--I don't want you to lose the run of the map--well, take your toy-horse, James Fitz-James, if you must have it--and run along with you.	Don't interrupt me; Polly-I don't want you to lose the run of the map-well, take your toy horse, james Fitz james, if you must have it-and run along with you.
column3: true

column2: Here, now--the soap will do for Babylon. Let me see--where was I? Oh yes--now we run down to Stone's Lan--Napoleon--now we run down to Napoleon.
column3: Here, now-the soap will do for Babylon. Let me see-where was I? Oh yes-now we run down to Stone's Lan-Napoleon-now we run down to Napoleon.

column2: Beautiful road.
column3: Beautiful road.

column2: Look at that, now.
column3: Look at that, now.

column2: Perfectly straight line-straight as the way to the grave.
column3: Perfectly straight line straight as the way to the grave.

column2: And see where it leaves Hawkeye-clear out in the cold, my dear, clear out in the cold.
column3: And see where it leaves Hawkeye clear out in the cold, my dear, clear out in the cold.

column2: That town's as bound to die as--well if I owned it I'd get its obituary ready, now, and notify the mourners.
column3: That town's as bound to die as-well if I owned it I'd get its obituary ready, now, and notify the mourners.

column2: Polly, mark my words--in three years from this, Hawkeye'll be a howling wilderness. You'll see.
column3: Polly, mark my words-in three years from this, Hawkeye'll be a howling wilderness. You'll see.

column2: And just look at that river--noblest stream that meanders over the thirsty earth!--calmest, gentlest artery that refreshes her weary bosom!
column3: And just look at that river-noblest stream that meanders over the thirsty earth!--calmest, gentlest artery that refreshes her weary bosom!

column2: Railroad goes all over it and all through it--wades right along on stilts.
column3: Railroad goes all over it and all through it-wades right along on stilts.

column2: Seventeen bridges in three miles and a half--forty-nine bridges from Hark-from-the-Tomb to Stone's Landing altogether--forty nine bridges, and culverts enough to culvert creation itself! Hadn't skeins of thread enough to represent them all--but you get an idea--perfect trestle-work of bridges for seventy two miles: Jeff Thompson and I fixed all that, you know; he's to get the contracts and I'm to put them through on the divide.
column3: Seventeen bridges in three miles and a half-forty nine bridges from Hark from the Tomb to Stone's Landing altogether-forty nine bridges, and culverts enough to culvert creation itself! Hadn't skeins of thread enough to represent them all-but you get an idea-perfect trestle work of bridges for seventy two miles: Jeff Thompson and I fixed all that, you know; he's to get the contracts and I'm to put them through on the divide.

column2: Just oceans of money in those bridges.
column3: Just oceans of money in those bridges.

column2: It's the only part of the railroad I'm interested in,--down along the line--and it's all I want, too.
column3: It's the only part of the railroad I'm interested in,--down along the line-and it's all I want, too.

column2: It's enough, I should judge. Now here we are at Napoleon.
column3: It's enough, I should judge. Now here we are at Napoleon.

column2: Good enough country plenty good enough--all it wants is population.
column3: Good enough country plenty good enough-all it wants is population.

column2: That's all right--that will come.
column3: That's all right-that will come.

column2: And it's no bad country now for calmness and solitude, I can tell you--though there's no money in that, of course.
column3: And it's no bad country now for calmness and solitude, I can tell you-though there's no money in that, of course.

column2: No money, but a man wants rest, a man wants peace--a man don't want to rip and tear around all the time. And here we go, now, just as straight as a string for Hallelujah--it's a beautiful angle--handsome up grade all the way--and then away you go to Corruptionville, the gaudiest country for early carrots and cauliflowers that ever--good missionary field, too.
column3: No money, but a man wants rest, a man wants peace-a man don't want to rip and tear around all the time. And here we go, now, just as straight as a string for Hallelujah-it's a beautiful angle-handsome up grade all the way-and then away you go to Corruptionville, the gaudiest country for early carrots and cauliflowers that ever-good missionary field, too.

column2: There ain't such another missionary field outside the jungles of Central Africa.
column3: There ain't such another missionary field outside the jungles of Central Africa.

column2: And patriotic?--why they named it after Congress itself.
column3: And patriotic?--why they named it after Congress itself.

column2: Oh, I warn you, my dear, there's a good time coming, and it'll be right along before you know what you're about, too.
column3: Oh, I warn you, my dear, there's a good time coming, and it'll be right along before you know what you're about, too.

column2: That railroad's fetching it.
column3: That railroad's fetching it.

column2: You see what it is as far as I've got, and if I had enough bottles and soap and boot-jacks and such things to carry it along to where it joins onto the Union Pacific, fourteen hundred miles from here, I should exhibit to you in that little internal improvement a spectacle of inconceivable sublimity.
column3: You see what it is as far as I've got, and if I had enough bottles and soap and boot jacks and such things to carry it along to where it joins onto the Union Pacific, fourteen hundred miles from here, I should exhibit to you in that little internal improvement a spectacle of inconceivable sublimity.

column2: So, don't you see?
column3: So, don't you see?

column2: We've got the rail road to fall back on; and in the meantime, what are we worrying about that $200,000 appropriation for?
column3: We've got the rail road to fall back on; and in the meantime, what are we worrying about that two hundred thousand dollars appropriation for?

column2: That's all right.
column3: That's all right.

column2: I'd be willing to bet anything that the very next letter that comes from Harry will--"
column3: I'd be willing to bet anything that the very next letter that comes from Harry will-"

column2: The eldest boy entered just in the nick of time and brought a letter, warm from the post-office.
column3: The eldest boy entered just in the nick of time and brought a letter, warm from the post office.

column2: Things do look bright, after all, Beriah.	Things do look bright, after all, Beriah.
column3: false

column2: I'm sorry I was blue, but it did seem as if everything had been going against us for whole ages.
column3: I'm sorry I was blue, but it did seem as if everything had been going against us for whole ages.

column2: Open the letter--open it quick, and let's know all about it before we stir out of our places.
column3: Open the letter-open it quick, and let's know all about it before we stir out of our places.

column2: I am all in a fidget to know what it says."
column3: I am all in a fidget to know what it says."

column2: The letter was opened, without any unnecessary delay.
column3: The letter was opened, without any unnecessary delay.

column2: Part 4.
column3: Part four.
